title: How to Create an Artsy Coffee Table

steps.headline: Sand your wooden table and wipe away the dust.
steps.description: If your table is made of wood, prepare it by sanding it with a medium grit sandpaper. Sand off finish, paint, or any other top coat from the surface. After sanding, use a damp cloth to wipe away the mess. If your table is made out of metal or plastic, there’s no need to sand it unless it’s painted. If necessary, sand off old paint. If it’s unpainted, just clean it up and wipe away any dirt or dust.

steps.headline: Paint a coat of flat white or black paint.
steps.description: If you have an extra gallon of flat paint lying around, use it as a primer. Priming your table will reduce the amount of chalkboard paint you’ll need. If you don’t have any extra flat paint, pick up some up from the hardware store. Using an inexpensive paint as a primer instead of applying more coats of chalkboard paint will save you some money. Flat paint is matte, or the opposite of high gloss paint. A glossy first coat wouldn't be as receptive to additional coats as a flat coat.

steps.headline: Add 1 to 2 coats of chalkboard paint.
steps.description: After the primer is completely dry, add your first coat of chalkboard paint. For a uniform look, paint the entire surface of your tabletop, including the edges. Let it dry, then add another coat if the color is uneven or patchy. If you have a table made of a grainy wood, use a bristled paintbrush instead of a roller or sponge brush. You’ll have an easier time getting into the grain with a bristled brush. If you’d like, hold off painting the legs or base so you can later add a high contrast color.

steps.headline: Paint the legs a contrasting color (optional).
steps.description: Painting the entire table one color would be fine, but painting the legs or base a fresh, contrasting color will add interest. For example, a high gloss white would look great with black chalkboard paint. Depending on your room’s color scheme, you could go with a pop of turquoise, orange, or another bright color. Look for a color in a rug, curtain, or accessory that you could echo with the table legs. Paint the legs after the top is dry so you can turn the table over to reach the base’s nooks and crannies.

steps.headline: Sand and wipe your wooden table.
steps.description: If you’re starting out with a wooden table, you’ll have to prep it by sanding the surface with medium grit sandpaper. After you’ve removed any paint or finish, wipe away the dust with a damp cloth. Wood furniture needs to be sanded to make the surface receptive to new coats of paint or decoupage glue. If you have an unpainted plastic or metal table, you can just wipe off any dirt and grime.

steps.headline: Plan your decoupage composition.
steps.description: You can create a collage using pictures of friends and family, or any other images you like. You could also cut wallpaper with a pattern or motif you think is cool to fit your tabletop. Whether you go with a collage or single sheet of paper, plan out your design before doing any actual gluing. Once you’ve put down glue, you won’t have time to come up with a composition on the fly.

steps.headline: Apply Mod Podge to the tabletop where you want to paste an image.
steps.description: You can purchase Mod Podge at your local crafts store or make your own by mixing 2 parts of white glue with 1 part of water. Use a sponge brush to paint a thin coat of Mod Podge on a small area where you’ll place your first image. If you're making a collage, work from one side of the tabletop to the other instead of gluing images at random. If you’re using one large sheet of paper, apply glue to the entire tabletop.

steps.headline: Place the image onto the tabletop immediately after applying Mod Podge.
steps.description: Stick your image onto the patch of glue as soon as possible. Use a rubber roller or spatula to prevent wrinkles, ridges, and bubbles. If any excess Mod Podge seeps around the edges of an image, just wipe it away with a cotton swab or damp cloth.

steps.headline: Continue applying Mod Podge and decorative elements.
steps.description: If you’re creating a collage, apply small patches of glue and add one piece of paper at a time. Keep repeating the process until you’ve covered the entire tabletop.

steps.headline: Apply a final coat of Mod Podge when the collage is dry.
steps.description: After you’ve covered the tabletop, give the glue about an hour to dry. When it’s dry, paint the entire surface with a final coat of Mod Podge. Use gentle, even strokes to prevent damaging the paper.

steps.headline: Gather enough flat bottle caps to cover your table.
steps.description: There’s no need to spend months or years saving up hundreds or thousands of flat bottle caps. You can purchase bottle caps on eBay and other online marketplaces. Keep in mind bottle caps that are bent from a bottle opener won’t work. When buying online, check an item’s description to make sure it lists them as flat. If you’re not into bottle caps, you could also use the same steps to make a penny-top table.

steps.headline: Calculate the number of bottle caps you’ll need.
steps.description: The number you need will depend on your tabletop’s size. The average bottle cap is 1.17 inches (3.0 cm). To get a rough idea, divide your tabletop’s length and width by a bottle cap’s diameter. For instance, if your table is 36 by 96 inches (91 by 244 cm), you can fit 30 rows and 82 columns of bottle caps. 30 multiplied by 82 is 2460, which is about how many bottle caps you’ll need.

steps.headline: Plan out how you’ll lay the bottle caps.
steps.description: It might be tedious, but you can’t skip the planning process. Lay out your bottle caps to double check your fit and, if you have multiple colors, to create attractive patterns.

steps.headline: Glue them down with a clear-drying craft glue.
steps.description: After laying down your bottle caps and creating a cool pattern, start gluing them one at a time to the tabletop. Apply a small amount of heavy duty craft glue to each bottle cap’s underside. When you're finished, give the glue 24 hours to dry. Glue the bottle caps from one side of the tabletop to the other instead of at random. That way, you won't accidentally miss one. Use a small amount of glue, and go for a clear-drying type so any excess won’t be visible.

steps.headline: Wrap the perimeter of your tabletop with wax paper or tin foil.
steps.description: After allowing the glue to dry for 24 hours, use painter’s tape to attach wax paper tightly around the table’s edge. Your goal is to make a 1 inch (2.5 cm) tall perimeter above the table's surface. This lip will act as a barrier and keep the epoxy from spilling over the tabletop. You can also make a perimeter using tin foil thinly coated with petroleum jelly. The epoxy won’t stick to wax paper or petroleum jelly, so you’ll be able to peel the perimeter away after it’s cured.

steps.headline: Mix the epoxy resin and hardener as directed.
steps.description: Epoxy is sold as resin and hardener, which create a chemical reaction when mixed together. Many products are mixed at a 2:1 ratio, but check your product’s instructions to be sure. A gallon of epoxy should be enough to cover your tabletop. Check your product’s label for information about how much surface area it can cover by volume. Wear gloves when you mix and pour epoxy.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture over the tabletop evenly.
steps.description: Keep the stream going across the entire surface to make an even coat. Take care not to overflow the wax paper perimeter. Use a float, which is a flat metal scraper tool, to even out the epoxy surface. Work in a well-ventilated area, and put a tarp under your work area to prevent making a mess.

steps.headline: Allow the tabletop to cure for 24 to 48 hours.
steps.description: After the surface has hardened and cured, peel off the wax paper or tin foil perimeter. Your artsy, one of a kind coffee table is now ready for use!
